string.text: Are you sure you want to disconnect?
Changes will take effect only after restarting the game!
Additional settings for any difficulty level
Are you sure you want to leave the Zone?
Are you sure you want to leave NLC7?
Loading a game will result in the loss of unsaved data. Do you wish to continue?
Saved game version mismatch or the save file is corrupted.
Are you sure you want to delete this file?
Press any key to start the game
A file with this name already exists. Overwrite it?
Click the 'Advanced' button to change settings added in OGSR
Hover your cursor over an option to see its description here. This will help you understand unfamiliar settings, as well as new ones added in OGSR
When this option is enabled, bullets fired from the hip will follow the direction of the weapon barrel rather than the center of the screen.

When hovering over an item in the inventory, a window will open with a detailed description of the item: suit and weapon stats, medical and food properties, repair kit contents, flask volume, and much more.
When enabled, camera bobbing will be disabled regardless of the character's state.
The number by which the character's total speed is multiplied. For example, if the character is tired, they will still move slower than normal, but faster relative to lower multiplier values.
Items in the trade window that the NPC will not buy for various reasons will be hidden.
MSAA is a very demanding yet high-quality type of anti-aliasing. It effectively smooths wires, vegetation, and semi-transparent geometry.

This setting adjusts the multiplier for the maximum visibility distance defined in the current weather profile. The range is from 0.4 (minimum slider) to 1.5 (maximum slider). For example, if the weather sets visibility to 150 meters, at minimum you will see 60 meters, and at maximum 225 meters. WARNING! High visibility distance can significantly reduce performance on older PCs.
This setting adjusts the level of detail for rendering and lighting of human models, monsters, and weapons. The further the slider, the more detailed they will appear at a distance.

This setting adjusts how densely grass tufts are rendered. The further the slider, the closer the grass elements will be to each other, making it thicker. WARNING! Excessive grass density leads to severe lag; adjust this parameter gradually and check the results.

This setting adjusts the maximum distance at which grass is rendered. The further the slider, the further the edge of the grass will be. It allows adjustment from 48m (standard) to 240m. WARNING! Due to the rendering algorithm, increasing the grass radius increases the GPU load exponentially. Acceptable values usually lie within 150-200 meters (middle of the slider).
This setting enables an optimized grass rendering mode by "thinning it out" at long distances. This helps gain a few FPS when using high values for draw distance and density.
This setting adjusts the level of texture detail. The further the slider, the sharper the textures and the more VRAM they require. Lowering this will blur textures but consume less memory.

This setting adjusts the level of anisotropic texture filtering. The minimum corresponds to 1x, and the maximum to 16x. Higher values make textures look sharper at steep viewing angles and at a distance.
This setting enables bullet impact marks (bloodstains) on character and monster bodies.
This setting enables objects to cast shadows from sunlight. Disabling this can significantly boost performance on weak PCs.

This setting enables grass to cast shadows from the sun and other dynamic light sources. This feature has been fixed and now works. WARNING! This setting is EXTREMELY taxing on performance. Do not use it with a large grass render radius or high density!
This setting adjusts the accuracy of lighting calculations over distance. Higher values make shadows from dynamic light sources look more detailed at a distance.
This setting allows the game to treat the volumetric light from NPC flashlights as dynamic light sources. Disabling this can give a serious performance boost at night in camps with many NPCs.
This setting adjusts the shadow rendering quality. Higher values result in smoother shadow edges.

This setting enables Vertical Synchronization, which syncs the frame rate with the monitor's refresh rate. This eliminates screen tearing during rapid movement but may slightly increase input lag or reduce performance.

This setting forces the game to use a 60Hz refresh rate. This is useful for monitors where the game incorrectly detects the refresh rate at startup. It is only recommended to enable this if you are experiencing such issues. In rare cases, it can cause lag in fullscreen mode.

This setting switches the anti-aliasing type. Available options: NVIDIA DLSS (Deep Learning Super Sampling), AMD FSR2 (FidelityFX Super Resolution), TAA (Temporal Anti-Aliasing), and SMAA (Subpixel Morphological Anti-Aliasing). 
 
NVIDIA DLSS is a revolutionary AI-based rendering technology that improves graphics quality using dedicated Tensor Cores in GeForce RTX GPUs. It provides results superior to MSAA 8x without the performance hit. 
 
FSR is a less demanding alternative from AMD. FSR 2.0 is supported by AMD RX 400 series and newer, as well as NVIDIA 1000 series and newer.

This setting adjusts the degree of light reflection from shiny and matte surfaces, such as metal, leather, wood, etc. WARNING! This is a "matter of taste" setting—if you don't know exactly what you are doing, leave it at the default value. The further the slider, the stronger the reflection effect, but don't overdo it—at high values, surfaces start to look like they are wrapped in plastic.

This setting adjusts the distance up to which dynamic shadows are rendered in full quality. Beyond this distance, they begin to blur and their quality drops as the calculation switches to a simplified mode. The slider adjusts the value from 1 to 60 meters. This parameter should be configured alongside shadow resolution (in the configurator). The higher you set the slider, the higher the shadow map resolution should be to maintain good quality.

This setting adjusts the field of view within which shadows are rendered correctly. If this angle is insufficient, extra triangular artifacts will be visible at the edges of the screen. It is recommended to keep this setting at the maximum.
This effect may not look good on all terrain textures, as it requires proper height maps for every ground texture.
This setting enables the HDR Tone Mapping effect. It improves the image by emphasizing details that would otherwise lack contrast—small elements and edges—without making the image excessively bright.

This setting adjusts the intensity of the HDR Tone Mapping effect. WARNING! This is a "matter of taste" setting, if you don't know exactly what you are doing, leave it at default. Adjust in small steps, as excessive values make the image look surreal and bright areas become overexposed. Setting it too high will result in an HDR effect reminiscent of Fallout 3.
This setting adjusts the intensity of sunlight. The higher it is, the brighter the sunlit areas will be and the deeper the shadows will appear.

This setting adjusts the intensity of scattered light independent of the sun. The higher it is, the brighter all shaded areas in the game will be, and the paler the sun shadows will look. WARNING! This is a "matter of taste" setting. Increase it if the game feels too dark overall and brightness/contrast sliders aren't enough. It is not recommended to set it too high, as the image will lose its sense of depth and look flat.
This setting switches the type of sun shafts. Choose the one you like best.

This setting enables the softening effect for the edges of water surfaces. When enabled, water near the shore will gradually gain transparency until it becomes invisible, eliminating the harsh, noticeable boundary between water and land.

This setting enables the soft particles effect. It significantly improves the appearance of effects such as fire, smoke, explosions, sparks, etc. It is recommended to always keep this setting enabled.
This setting adjusts the softening of shadow edges in the game, making shadows look more realistic.
This setting adjusts the shadow softening effect for lamps as the distance from the source increases. This makes the lighting appear more realistic.

This setting enables precomputed global illumination. It uses pre-rendered hemi-lightmaps to bring the visuals closer to photorealism. Enabling this will make building interiors significantly darker. This setting does not affect performance since the effect is pre-calculated, but keep in mind that precomputed and dynamic GI (r2_ssao) effects stack. If you want to use both, it makes sense to lower the intensity of each to avoid an overly dark image. Alternatively, if performance is a priority, use only precomputed lighting and disable dynamic GI.
This setting adjusts the intensity of the precomputed global illumination. Higher values result in a more realistic image but cause the scene to become darker.

This setting adjusts the quality of AO (Ambient Occlusion). This effect calculates additional shading for areas occluded by geometry, making the lighting look more natural. It adds soft shadows to equipment, clothing, vehicle details, grass, and other small geometric elements.
This setting adjusts the operating mode of the global illumination effect. You can choose between GTAO (Ground Truth-based Ambient Occlusion) and SSDO (ScreenSpace Directional Occlusion).

This setting adjusts the enhanced surface relief effect using the Steep Parallax Mapping algorithm. This algorithm uses ray tracing within the height map space to calculate relief, providing a more realistic and high-quality effect.
This setting enables a component of the Depth of Field effect—real-time eye focusing. Some players find it distracting, so we have provided the option to disable it.
This setting enables a component of the Depth of Field effect—focusing the eyes on the weapon during reloading.
This setting enables a component of the Depth of Field effect—blurring the edges of the screen while aiming.
This setting adjusts the overall quality of the Depth of Field effect.
This setting enables Detail Bump mapping—displaying small details and surface roughness on objects.
Enables lens flares for light bulbs.
Enables the simulation of "dirt" on the camera lens.
Enables raindrops appearing on the glass of helmets and gas masks during rain.
Enables dynamic puddles that appear during rain.
Enables surfaces becoming wet during rain.
Enables volumetric lighting for certain lamps.
Enables reflections on various surfaces, including water and puddles during rain. Impacts FPS!
Tessellation increases the quality of low-poly models of NPCs, monsters, the player's hands, and animated items (bottles, etc.). Angular models become smoother.
Enables shader optimization mode. This can increase FPS on graphics cards with narrow memory buses or low memory bandwidth.

Allows you to adjust image sharpening. WARNING! This is a "matter of taste" setting and SHOULD NORMALLY BE DISABLED. Enable it ONLY if you prefer a grainy image. At high values, it produces a noticeable halo around objects.
Enables volumetric fog technology. It is used to simulate murky water, haze in lowlands, and similar effects.
Adjusts the sun's effective range. Reducing this can save FPS in sunny weather. You can try decreasing it by half; the visual difference is minor, but performance will improve.

Higher shadow map resolutions result in sharper distant shadows (beyond ~15-20 meters from the player, past the near shadow cascade). To avoid a noticeable drop in quality at this boundary, a resolution of at least 4096x4096 is recommended. This setting heavily impacts performance.
Activates simultaneous texture loading using multiple threads. May slightly reduce save loading times if using an SSD.
Increasing the Field of View is useful for wide monitors and depends on personal preference.

Player model FOV. A value of 0.45 or less (below the slider midpoint) brings the weapon closer; 0.65 or more (above the midpoint) makes the weapon appear further away. Should be adjusted based on monitor aspect ratio and main FOV.\n%c[red]A value of 0.70 is recommended for correct weapon display in this mod. It will be set automatically when starting a new game.

Adjusts the intensity of hemi-lighting. Higher values make the scene brighter. WARNING! This is a "matter of taste" setting—if you don't know exactly what you are doing, leave it at default. Increase it only if the game feels too dark and standard brightness/contrast sliders are insufficient.
Adjusts the frame rendering frequency for 3D scopes. By default, every second frame is rendered. Increasing this value boosts overall game FPS but reduces the smoothness (FPS) within the 3D scope.

If DLSS or FSR is enabled, this setting adjusts the image scaling within 3D scopes to improve clarity. %c[yellow] 
At a value of 1, the image is not scaled. %c[green] 
Optimal value: 2. %c[red] 
Values higher than 2 may cause a significant drop in FPS.

This setting adjusts the rendering distance for dynamic objects, excluding helicopters, crows, and vehicles. Higher distances mean more objects are processed by the renderer, which may lower FPS. %c[red] \nIn most cases, the default value of 250 meters is optimal. Increasing it is only recommended if you specifically require a higher object draw distance.
